posts.name: Quinton Rodgers
posts.cooked: If its actually “glowing” orange. Something has gone horribly wrong. If its just one of the LED’s. We will need more information about it to help you you

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
Idk what you all are reacting with " " about.

It’s just a built in energized warning lamp…

posts.name: Emre
posts.cooked: Hı, Yes, the light here is orange . For the orange color, we get the sticky error error and we don’t know how to solve it

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked: You can use one of the CTRE utilities (Phoenix Tuner / X) to clear the sticky fault on the PDP .  But, it’s not something you have to do – it’s OK to leave it alone.

posts.name: Carlos Gross Jones
posts.cooked: Yeah, that tells you that the ground is working.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Mere hours of work can save you entire minutes of planning

posts.custom_user_title: Mere hours of work can save you entire minutes of planning

posts.name: D_Price (1708 Co-Lead Mentor)
posts.cooked: Just a little spicy nut. Pun fully intended.

posts.name: Emre
posts.cooked: how do i do this from phonix tuner x? what should I do?

posts.name: Jake Potter
posts.cooked: TIL the PDP lights can be green

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: 1554 Mentor, 694 Alum, LRI, FIRST Long Island RPC

posts.custom_user_title: 1554 Mentor, 694 Alum, LRI, FIRST Long Island RPC

posts.cooked: The simple steps are: open the tuner, connect to the robot, go to the PDP device, click the button to clear the sticky faults.

posts.name: Davo
posts.cooked: Yeah, my team found out the funny way: I once hit the [blink / clear sticky faults] button in Phoenix Tuner, then everyone slowly discovered they’re meant to be green.

posts.name: Emre
posts.cooked: I understand, I will try this, thank you everyone
